p: Because of its high chemical stability and high photocatalytic activity, nano-TiO 2 has great development prospects in the fields of environmental protection [ 1], such as in photocatalytic disinfection, antibacterial use [ 2, 3], wastewater treatment [ 4], air purification [ 5], and so on. Especially in the face of the current difficulty of eliminating volatile organic compound (VOC) pollution in the air, TiO 2 photocatalysis technology has shown unique advantages [ 6, 7]. However, the preparation cost of nano-TiO 2 is high, and the process is difficult to control, meaning that nano-TiO 2 has poor dispersion and a wide particle-size distribution. Moreover, the photocatalytic performance restricts its development and application: firstly, the band gap of 3.2 eV limits it to using only ultraviolet light below 387.5 nm in wavelength [ 8]. Secondly, the electron and hole produced by the light excitation of TiO 2 recombine very easily [ 9, 10]. Therefore, developing preparation technology of TiO 2 with good dispersion and a uniform particle size and exploring a way to broaden the light response range and inhibit the electron and hole recombination of TiO 2 are the key problems which need to be solved urgently in order to develop the commercialization and advanced application of nano-TiO 2.
